hints_html:
Use a trigonometric identity to rewrite the integrand.

\(\sin(2x) = 2\sin (x)\cos(x)\).

Alternative solution: Use a substitution.
hints_latex: Use a trigonometric identity to rewrite the integrand.
hints_raw:
Use a trigonometric identity to rewrite the integrand.
<math> \sin(2x) = 2\sin (x)\cos(x)</math>.
Alternative solution: Use a substitution.
question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
We first solve the indefinite integral, using the trigonometric identity \(\sin(2x) = 2\sin(x)\cos(x)\):

\[\begin{aligned} \int \sin(\pi x)\cos(\pi x)\,dx &= \int \frac12 \sin(2\pi x)\,dx \\ &=-\frac1{4\pi}\cos(2\pi x) + C. \end{aligned}\]

Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} I_1 &= \int_{1/2}^1 \sin(\pi x)\cos(\pi x)\,dx \\ &= \left.\frac{-1}{4\pi}\cos(2\pi x)\right|_{1/2}^1 \\ &= \frac{-1}{4\pi} \cos(2\pi) + \frac1{4\pi} \cos(\pi) \\ &= -\frac1{4\pi} - \frac1{4\pi}= -\frac1{2\pi}. \end{aligned}\]

Alternatively, substitute \(u = \sin(\pi x).\) Then \(du = \pi \cos(\pi x)dx\), when \(x=1/2\) then \(u = \sin(\pi/2) = 1\), and when \(x=1\) then \(u = \sin(\pi) = 0.\) Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} I_1 &= \int_{1/2}^1 \sin(\pi x)\cos(\pi x)\,dx \\ &= \int_1^0 u \cos(\pi x)\frac{du}{\pi \cos(\pi x)} \\ &= \frac1{\pi} \int_1^0 u\,du \\ &= \left.\frac1{2\pi}u^2\right|_1^0 \\ &= - \frac1{2\pi}.\end{aligned}\]
